content:
SECTION 1: INTRODUCTORY PROBLEMS # Exercise 1 # Solving with brute force cost \(O(n^n)\) time.
Which is not what we want…
\(S[1] = A[1] + A[2] + … + A[n] \Rightarrow O(n)\)
\(S[2] = A[2] + A[3] + … + A[n+1] \Rightarrow O(n)\)
\(S[n] = A[n] + A[n+1] + … + A[2n-1] \Rightarrow O(n)\)
Solution
Using the value from the preivious iteration would simplify the time complexity.
\(S[1] = A[1] + A[2] + … + A[n] \Rightarrow O(n)\)
\(S[2] = S[1] - A[1] + A[n+1] \Rightarrow O(1)\)
\(S[n] = S[n-1] - A[n-1] + A[2n-1] \Rightarrow O(1)\)
Exercise 2 # (a) # Solution
Create an array of size n with all zero, lets call it count.
Iterate through A, let c be the current element
if count[c] equals 0 then set count[c] to 1 else c is the duplicate, terminate the program (b) # Solution
let k be the duplicate number
\(\sum*{i=1}^{n}A[i] - \sum*{i=1}^{n-1}A[i] = k\)
Exercise 3 # (a) # To only determines if a number exist which can be written as a sum of two distinct numbers from A in two different ways, we can create an array which stores all possible sum from each distinc numbers.
After that, we run mergesort to the new array so that the duplicate numbers are next to each other, then it would be easy to find duplicate. If there are duplicates, that means there exists a number that satisfy the condition.
Solution
Create an Array named S Iterate for i: 1 to n: Iterate for j: i to n: insert A[i] + A[j] to S, where i != to j Mergesort S Iterate S: if any of S[i] = S[i+1], then it exists nested for loop = \(O(n^2)\)
mergesort S = \(O(n^2 \log_2 n^2)\) = \(O(2 * n^2 \log_2 n)\) = \(O(n^2 log_2 n)\)
iterate S = \(O(n^2)\)
nested for loop + mergesort S + iterate S
= \(O(n^2) + O(n^2 log_2 n) + O(n^2)\)
= \(O(n^2 log_2 n)\)
(b) # By using a hash table instead of an array, we would know if duplicate exists before inserting to the hash table. (Note that on average hashtable lookups and insertion only takes O(1), so we can claim that the two operations has \(O(1)\) expected time).
Solution
Create an HashTable named S Iterate for i: 1 to n: Iterate for j: i to n: if A[i] + A[j] in S, it exists! insert A[i] + A[j] to S, where i != to j nested for loop = \(O(n^2)\)
insert to hash table = \(O(1)\)
lookups for hash table = \(O(1)\)
insert and lookups are inside of the nested for loop, which makes the overall time complexity still being \(O(n^2)\)
SECTION 2: SEARCHING ALGORITHMS # SECTION 3: SORTING ALGORITHMS # SECTION 4: TIME COMPLEXITY ANALYSIS #
title: COMP3121 Problem Set 1

content:
This is a demo site built using HUGO and Blowfish . It also contains a complete set of previous projects. Blowfish is flexible and is great for both static page-based content (like this demo) or a traditional blog with a feed of recent posts.
This is a demo of the profile layout.Switch layout ↻Explore the sample pages to get a feel for what Blowfish can do. If you like what you see, check out the project on Github or read the Installation guide to get started.
summary: This is a demo site built using HUGO and Blowfish . It also contains a complete set of previous projects. Blowfish is flexible and is great for both static page-based content (like this demo) or a traditional blog with a feed of recent posts.
